Let's denote the event "UK leaves EU <= 31 Oct 2019" as A.
In my view, P(A) = P(A1) + P(A2), where
A1 is the event "UK leaves with the deal",
A2 is the event "UK leaves without the deal". I estimate P(A1)<=5% in the view of the very last news (https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-46393399). I couldn't find historical examples where such a long beurocratic procedure (described on the diagram in the article) took less than couple of weeks. I estimate P(A2)<=5%. In my view the operation "Yellowhammer" is mostly the way to publicly demonstrate the UK government's determination and consistency, and to strengthen their negotiating position. (see https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2019/oct/22/operation-yellowhammer-brexit-preparations).

UK’s Johnson seeks Dec. 12 election to break Brexit impasse Lawless (2019) October 24, states that: LONDON (AP) — British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has finally abandoned his promise of an October Brexit and pinned his hopes on a December election (Para. 1). Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn said he would wait and see whether the EU agreed to delay Britain’s departure from the bloc. Johnson grudgingly asked for a three-month delay until Jan. 31 on the orders of Britain’s Parliament, which wants to avert the economic damage that could come from a no-deal exit (Para. 7). “Take no-deal off the table and we absolutely support a general election,” Corbyn said. He said that “if the EU will answer tomorrow then we’ll know tomorrow.” Smaller opposition parties said they wanted an election but were wary of doing it on Johnson’s terms. “The U.K. government has no coherent plan to end the Brexit chaos and a general election will not solve the crisis,” said Adam Price, leader of the Welsh party Plaid Cymru (Para 7-11). *

from what I can understand the state of play is that the uk parliament voted to first get johnson's deal into UK Law before agreeing on it. that is, the deal has to be legal, that is why the vote has been delayed.  making the deal legal means pass the withdrawal agreement bill (WAB). for the uk to leave the EU on or before 31 October the WAB has to be passed with no major amendments. with the first vote for WAB coming Tuesday 22 October. if WAB passes then MPs are willing to back a deal, in principle if WAB passes, then Brexit is back on track. if WAB fails, then EU must agree to having an extension or not. granting an extension requires all 27 EU nations to agree on it, and it they don't then there is a no deal Brexit.  so the yes answer to this question either requires i) both WAB and the EU extension to fail or ii) WAB to pass without any major amendments I think WAB will pass but then be withdrawn after major amendments meaning the EU would probably grant an extension.

I am revising my forecast down for a thematic reason: I am highly pessimistic that Parliament can pass a bill of this magnitude with the dearth of debate demanded to get Brexit done by Oct. 31. I decided to investigate how quickly these things are usually done and Parliament has a little study on this: https://researchbriefings.parliament.uk/ResearchBriefing/Summary/SN03341#fullreport.  From the abstract: "Of the six Bills linked to EC/EU Treaties, Parliament spent most time on the Maastricht Treaty (41 days), closely followed by the original membership process (39 days). Lisbon came third with 25 days. Lisbon gave rise to the largest number of divisions, although a number of these were not on the Bill itself but concerned government policy in various policy areas relevant to the Lisbon Treaty". Below, the time each bill took on the floor: Treaty of Rome: 39 days
Single European Act: 12 days
Treaty on European Union (Maastricht): 41 days
Treaty of Amsterdam: 16 days
Treaty of Nice: 11 days
Treaty of Lisbon: 25 days That is an average time of 24 days, from HC 1R (formal) to Royal Assent. The government would have to beat the Treaty of Nice's time to get this over the line and finish the saga. Let's not forget that once Royal Assent has been granted, the game does not end there, the ball is knocked over to the EU.  Lastly, I am straining to see how Boris Johnson avoids sending the letter to the EU. I do not want to make the mistake of not taking him at his word, so I assume he is looking at ways to end this this month, but contempt of Parliament is essentially what he would have to do, short of posting the requisite letter in snail mail...

The PM will send the required letter, but hoonose by what glacial means he will transmit it, what other contradictory communications may accompany or succeed it, or what he or his gummint may backchannel to one or more of the states that must give the okey-dokey. It still looks very much like his preference is for a no-deal crashout, which he may suppose will make him look or at least feel heroic.  No matter what the Commons may think, the PM still has all the cards.

Getting an extension seems less likely in view of Macron's "It is time to put end to negotiations and move on to future relationship’" statement, (https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2019/oct/18/brexit-extension-unavoidable-if-mps-reject-deal-says-merkel), but as this was not a categorical refusal to grant an extension, I am not absolutely sold, especially as I keep thinking there are technical issues that cannot possibly be resolved in so short a time frame, but there is a desire to be done with this. However, as the article points out, Merkel, the bell-weather of the EU leadership, has what I think is a realistic assessment: an extension must be granted if requested.  I think though the odds of Brexit happening this month have dramatically increased. The Parliamentary math (https://www.parliament.uk/mps-lords-and-offices/mps/current-state-of-the-parties/) is not unfavourable, as this Bloomberg analysis shows: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-10-18/can-johnson-pull-off-the-impossible-we-re-counting-the-votes?srnd=politics-vp. Given the imprecision in the math, it is hard to have a narrow assessment. Boris Johnson needs 61 of 85 available MPs. Can he get them? I am assuming the DUP (10MPs) aligns in toto against the deal because it represents a betrayal of the coalition. This may be compensated for by the Labour MPs who will side with him -around 9, but let's say 10 for good measure, though Bloomberg says 31 are up for grabs (https://news.yahoo.com/brexit-rebel-labour-mps-defy-171030559.html). Let's be generous and say he gets the ‘Gaukeward Squad’: 19 MPs, The Spartans: 28 MPs, Independents: 5 MPs, Liberal Democrat Norman Lamb and Boris Johnson's brother, Jo. So, of those available 85, I see a route to 54, with Labour MPs (I think 10 or more) potentially tipping him over. There is a route to victory, which relies on Labour MPs and not bleeding Tory votes. CNN's analysis suggests Boris Johnson has a slight edge in the race. Overall, I am optimistic about Boris Johnson's chances of success. So why am I not completely sold on Brexit by Oct. 31? Firstly, the Letwin amendment (https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-parliaments-50098128) is designed to prevent a scenario where Brexit is achieved without a deal being finalized legislatively. As I said in the beginning, I cannot imagine that such a momentous step can or should be rushed through in under a fortnight. Given Letwin, there may not even be a vote this Saturday. So the vote tomorrow could essentially be meaningless if the Letwin amendment passes. My "35%" yes is purely instinctive. It feels like the right number, or maybe the wrong number in the right range.

Continuing to feel comfortable at 10%, but I wanted to throw out an interesting read: https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-10-16/will-u-k-parliament-back-a-boris-johnson-brexit-we-do-the-math As the odds of a deal being struck between London and Brussels increases, the question turns to whether Johnson will meet the same fate as May and lose in Parliament.  Seems like Johnson needs 61 of 85 uncommitted MPs (72%). Based on what I’m reading, the following is my base-case (names from the article):
- Gaukeward Squad: 10 (that’s half of the group)
- DUP: 5 (a generous 50% given some vocal concerns)
- Spartans: 16 (they seem to be dependent on the DUP, so this could go south fast. Generous, since a probability-weighting would only yield 8)

The Queen just read out Boris Johnson's stump speech McGee (2019) October 14, states that: London (CNN) The pageantry may be over, but the UK's bumper Brexit week has only just begun. There are two avenues to blocking No Deal Brexit, the first is to bring down the government and the second is to force the government to seek an extension. The first avenue is itself blocked: the opposition and those MPs willing to align themselves with the opposition, cannot coalesce behind any leader: Corbyn is unacceptable and will not stand down, and the SNP & LibDems are too small, and there is a question about having the SNP lead the government of the United Kingdom when its goal is to leave it. Legally, a vote of no confidence would not immediately result in a general election and so the only way to force a rapid change of government would be to vote on an early day motion (EDM), which would be a vote of confidence in a specific individual, and so we get back to the leadership question the opposition has. The Benn Act, then, to my mind, is the last stand against No Deal. I have looked at John Major's notion that the government could get round the Benn Act through an order in council, but i think the whole business unlikely and even the government has dismissed the idea -which could be through sand in our eyes, but to what end? There are a few loopholes in the Benn Act: if parliament agrees to a deal, then the government is absolved of its responsibility to send a letter requesting an extension. The other loophole is that the Prime Minister must accept an extension according to the parameters detailed in his letter, which requests an extension till January 31 2020. In other words, if the European Council proposed an extension outside of this date, the Prime Minister need not accept the extension. More on this here: https://ukconstitutionallaw.org/2019/09/13/oliver-garner-the-benn-burt-extension-act-a-roadblock-to-a-no-deal-brexit/. There is the possibility of some nation, like Hungary, vetoing an extension request, but judging by Juncker and Varadkar's statements, this is extremely unlikely considering the nations most affected by Brexit -France, Germany, etc- have little incentive to veto an extension, this would imply a country like Hungary acting against the interests of France and Germany... The government could simply throw its toys out of the pram and veto key decisions and make itself such a nuisance the EU vetoes an extension request, but with only a week left, that would be quite a tantrum. Finally, civil servants are obliged to follow the law and if they perceive the government to be breaking the law, they may simply not co-operate in enforcing its will. All this rambling leads me to think that the Prime Minister is attempting to drive a bus through the eye of a needle. There is a gulf between rhetoric and reality and I keep asking myself: if Boris Johnson could get round the Benn Act, why has he not announced how he will do it? In 2019, leaks are inevitable, and yet, nothing... Boris Johnson cannot remain Prime Minister, uphold the law and exit on 31 Oct. 2019.

The EU should think twice before rejecting Boris Johnson’s proposal Münchau (2019) October 6, states that: The member states of the EU have a common negotiating position on Brexit, but they have different ulterior motives. (Para. 1). There is one group, led by Germany, whose priority is to avoid a no-deal Brexit in order to minimize disruption to industrial supply chains. Another group, led by France, seeks to stop the UK from exploiting the opportunities for regulatory arbitrage. The French fear that a Singapore on Thames might undercut EU standards on social policy and the environment. Then there is a third group that wants the UK to reverse Brexit altogether, as a symbol of the fightback against the rising global tide of populism. What all three have in common is a lack of interest in agreeing to engage with UK prime minister Boris Johnson’s proposals for the withdrawal deal. They are reassured that the Brexit extension bill passed by the House of Commons has removed the threat of an immediate no-deal Brexit. Legal documents submitted to a Scottish court state that Mr Johnson intends to comply with the requirements of the Benn Act and seek a Brexit delay if he cannot secure a deal. But even if the deadline is extended once more, the EU should think twice before rejecting the latest UK plan. It is trivially true that an extension buys time, avoids disruption on the day, and maybe even opens up a theoretical path towards a Brexit reversal. But rejection would still be a short-sighted strategy. If the process is allowed to stray past the current October 31 deadline, the EU will have to live with the consequences of rejecting the deal (Para. 1-4). **

Prime Minister Boris Johnson offers a new Brexit plan, new suspension of Parliament Adam, Birnbaum and Booth (2019) October 2, states that: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson bounced onto the stage at the annual Conservative Party conference in Manchester Wednesday and announced what he said were “constructive and reasonable proposals” for getting a Brexit deal done by the end of October. He was cheered in the conference hall. But his long-awaited written plan was met with raised eyebrows in Europe and roundly dismissed by opposition lawmakers in Britain. Johnson didn’t win any additional support when, hours later, his spokesman announced that the government would seek to suspend — or “prorogue” — Parliament from Oct. 8 through Oct. 14, when Queen Elizabeth II would come to the the chamber to deliver the “Queen’s Speech” and lay out a new agenda (Para. 1-3). In a letter to European President Jean-Claude Juncker detailing his new proposals Wednesday, Johnson reiterated his opposition to the Irish “backstop” — negotiated by his predecessor Theresa May to guarantee an open border on the island of Ireland. Johnson said his government was seeking a more decisive split from the European Union (Para. 5). “In these circumstances, the proposed ‘backstop’ is a bridge to nowhere, and a new way forward must be found,” he wrote (Para. 5-6).
The E.U. has in the past resisted such checks on the grounds that they could jeopardize the delicate peace established by the 1998 Good Friday agreement (Para. 8). [Within only one month, Boris Johnson lost control — and a historic Supreme Court battle] The proposals were not immediately rejected in Brussels or other European capitals, as has at times been the case following British negotiation gambits. Several analysts, though, said the prospect of a breakthrough didn’t look good. Johnson’s plan appears to cross red lines drawn years ago by European negotiators. Juncker cited “positive advances,” especially the proposal to keep many Northern Ireland regulations aligned with E.U. standards. But he said that there were “problematic points” related to Britain’s apparent unwillingness to commit to keeping the border fully and permanently open (Para. 8-11). ***__

Nothing simpler.  The PM presents plans for something or other.  These do not pass the giggle test, either in Parliament or with the EU.   The 20th of October arrives and the deadline is missed.  Some Leaver in the Parliament proposes a couple or nine amendments to the law which ostensibly requires the PM to send a request for extension.   Swatting these down eats up a couple of days.  The PM writes some version of the required letter and asks the House to approve the wording, knowing they won't.   The extended chat about that eats up a couple of days.  It is now the 25th and everyone at Number 10 knocks off for the weekend. On Monday afternoon a staffer puts the required letter in a regular envelope with the wrong address handwritten on it and no return address and posts it at a regular box, carefully missing the last pickup time.  It gets to Brussels on Wednesday the 30th and comes to the EU mailroom where it languishes because it looks ordinary.  It is delivered to somebody or other on the morning of 1 November.   Too bad.  The PM is furious and defenestrates some low-level clerk who has previously agreed to this arrangement.   And that's only the easiest way to deal with it, assuming the PM does not wish to flout the law too flagrantly.  There is no evidence that he is averse to that approach, of course, there being no likely penalty for doing so.

There are now very few ways which UK can leave on 31st: 1) Boris Johnson resigns before extension request deadline so he is no longer compelled to ask for extension and MPs can't agree new PM in time to ask for extension. 
2) EU Council denies UK extension
3) EU Council attaches unacceptable condition to extension according to UK parl 
4) UK gov successfully challenges EU Withdrawal Act in courts and rules they are not compelled to ask for extension
5) UK gov achieves concessions and is able to pass a Withdrawal Agreement through parliament
6) MPs take control of parl business and propose the WA which gets passed through parliament There are probably more ways too but these are 6 outcomes which I don't think are particularly likely that could feasibly happen. Hence the low probably of a 31st exit.

The Prime Minister has lost his majority, and it is unlikely that an election will be held before the 31st October. The law compels Johnson to ask for an extension if no new deal can be reached. Parliament does not want to leave without a deal and could well form an alternative government to secure an extension, then dissolve the parliament. The political calculus for the labour party is that passing any deal does not benefit them, and it is very unlikely that any deal will be significantly different from the withdrawal agreement which failed earlier this year. No deal is the legal default but a temporary government to ask for an extension would become likely in that case.

The recent court cases - one in Scotland and one in England - providing different verdicts over the last week [Scot rules that parliament should be sitting / whilst Eng courts ruled the PM had not done anything unlawful] - therefore the decision will go to the Supreme Court - this case will be on Tuesday 17th Sept -  Even if Johnson wins the vote [i.e. the supreme court rules that his actions were not unlawful] and that therefore parliament does not come back until mid Oct - all things considered it is unlikely that the PM will be able to put anything to parliament to exit with a deal before the 31st Oct - there is the EU meeting on the 17th Oct but with the EU negotiating team stating that the UK has not put anything new on the table this outcome looks doubtful -  If supreme court rules that Johnson did act unlawfully, then parliament will resume its current session - MP's will probably look to force Johnson to ask EU for an extension - if he refuses [i.e. resigns] then a general election is the most probable next step - Labour and Lib Dems are currently playing political games to delay the chance of a general election until November - their priority is to avoid a No Deal exit at all costs  There are still plenty of other possible outcomes and unknowables to be certain of anything - but with the PM having literally no control over the order of business in parliament - and the fact that parliament [MP's] are very much a remain institution [75% voted to remain] - this is likely to drag on well past the 31st Oct
